name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: The Earth

transcript.content: Testing, testing.
This is almost the environment more than... the Earth
It is, isn't it?
We already publicized it is the 'Earth'.
Well, yeah, but it doesn't matter. I mean, yeah, but that's fine. The Earth.
Why is it the Earth?
We talked abou-- What?
I said, what do you mean "Why is it called the Earth?"
You mean, why is the Earth called "the Earth"?
Why is Mars called "Mars"?
It's just something I never say. I never say Earth. I always say World.

Well, it depends. It's not called the World, is it? Because a world... it's relative? Mars is a world. It's The World, because it's our world. But there are many worlds, aren't there? You could say "the world of something", you couldn't say "the Earth of something". The Earth is the name of the planet.
But when do we need that?
What?
When do we need to say "the Earth"?
When we're referring to the Earth.
When does that ever happen?
Well, for instance, right now when we're talking about the Earth, being that this is the name of this
If I was in a--
To distinguish it from other planets.
If I was in-- I know, but when's that ever going to be a problem. For me?
What?? It's not all about you!
If I was in a rocket...
Yeah. Right, here we go!
...And sat at the front.
"Sat at the front"!
He's got a good seat, yeah.
The pilot goes: "Karl, can I... (unintelligible)
And I look in the mirror and I see
Mirror! Mirror in the rocket...
"Mirror, check. Reverse. Indicate. Brilliant.
And I see the world. I'd say, "Look, the world! Looks magnificent."
What do you mean?
Yeah, that's how I'd say it. I wouldn't say "Earth". I wouldn't dream of using the word "Earth"
But then you could say, well, this is our world now. For the next year, this is our world, this spaceship.
No, not really. I'd always be looking back over there. I'm looking up there, there's our world. There's England, there.

"Not anymore, mate. We're moving to Mars. We're going to start a whole new world." "Oh, which world are you talking about, Karl? Let's call it the Earth and Mars like we always have, you dopey cunt!" That's the name of this planet, we're on!

That's what I'm saying, though. It's not our problem. We're never going to leave it. So it's our world, so leave it as "World". It's a bit of information. You don't write: so and so road, London, England, Earth. You don't need it.
What other words are you annoyed by? Other words are out there, you're thinking "Why is that there? Because we do not need it!"
It's one of them where I come across something. They're not always in me head. It's just-- I think of something I've seen recently, that's a word...
I'll say some words, Karl. You tell me whether you like them or not! Okay? Yeah?
"Route"
What sort of "route" are we talking about?
Good question. What about... a pre planned journey?
No, you don't need it. You just go, "which way are you going?" I thought you meant beetroot.
The vegetable
That's alright.
What, you don't mind beetroot?
It depends what I'm having.
Steve & Ricky laugh

He didn't mean the food, he means you don't mind the word existing. This is because you have such a limited vocabulary, that it annoys you and intimidates you that people are using words-- Correct words, the correct English language.
Are you happy with "chair"? Should we keep "chair"?
It works. It's fine.
Are you happy with the chair you sit on or the chair, who's in charge of like a forum, or a meeting? What would we call a bloke who's in charge of a meeting?
"Chief"
Chief? Okay? What about bloke who's in charge of...
Native Americans.
Native Americans.
I don't know any. Again, not going to affect my life.
No, but what would you call him? He's a bloke in charge there-- All the Indian or all the--
Seriously, not a problem to me.
It's a problem for someone!
Yeah.
So you've got to have a word for it.
Head Chief.
Head Chief?
Oh, so he's-- That means he's bloke in charge of people or in charge of meetings? "Arghh!"
That's confusing
I'm confused actually. I'm confused here.
I mean, some words I know you're not happy with, there are certain numbers you're not keen on? What, number 7? Would you get rid of that?
I've heard about that tribe where they-- It is just like they have three. They say, that's all they need in their life. One, two, three.
Really?
"Yeah. Give us three of them!" And then "Actually it give us another two with them three!" It's all like--
(laughing) I love the fact... That they're still talking like that.
Down at the market!
Yeah "We should have a word for this three and this two!" "Nah, fuck it! I very rarely want three then two."

Keep it three, then two. "How many do you need now?" "Just one. And another one" "Well, say two!" "Oh yeah, say two, yeah" "Do you want one more? "If I wanted three, I'd say three"! "Do you want one more?" "Yeah, give us three and one!"
Ricky sniffs
Intro music

As the writer and pioneering ecologist, Rachel Carson once wrote: "Those who dwell among the beauties and mysteries of the Earth, are never alone or weary of life." Earth, the third rock from the Sun, and the only known planet in the universe to accommodate life, was formed about 5 billion years ago. Extensively covered by saltwater oceans, it supports a myriad of organisms, the most evolved of which is man. Yet how we humans interact with our world could be sowing the seeds of our own destruction. With environmental concerns still high on the political agenda, what is the future of life on Earth? How are we coping with the threat of global warming? And is our newfound ecological concern too little, too late? To discuss the past, present and future of the Earth, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, award winning writer and graduate of the University of Warwick.
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington. (in a high pitched voice) "Oh, look at his little head, the Cuuuunt!"
Alright?
Ricky giggles

I've been hit by global warming recently, Rick. A couple of times, actually. I don't want to be one of those people that's like "Oh, you know, because of the snow and the rain... that's obviously do with global warming" but it probably is. I was flying out to the States, you know, just hopping over Stateside.
Yeah yeah.

And on the old plane... One of those bleak, kind of snowy days recently. They got us all on the plane. We sat on the runway. For four and a half hours! Four and a half hours, while they de-iced the plane. Now, it's good that they de-iced it, but I don't want to be told that the plane needs de-icing. I didn't know planes could get iced in a way that they needed to be de-iced. When I, sometimes Rick, if it's a chilly morning right? Got the old car, what I'll do is I'll pop the engine on
Yeah
Okay? Let it warm up, pop inside for another cup of tea, come back out, it's lovely and warm and toasty in there. That's what I'd like to see them do with the old plane.
The pilot goes "Don't you get on yet! Let me pop around the block."
"Let me warm it up"
Yeah, exactly.
But also, when it's up at 30,000ft, it's like -50, -60 degrees
That's it! It must get iced up anyway. There's not some guy on the wing, scraping it off with a plastic thing
"Ah, we got to pull in here! We got to pull in here for a while, it's iced up."
Yeah
Also, I didn't see anyone de-ice it, so I don't know how they do it. It's not presumable done with, you know-- Like sometimes how I use a CD case if I don't have one of those scrapers.
Yeah, yeah. That's good.

Don't know if there was people with, probably with the vinyl record scraping away... But yeah, four and a half hours to de-ice it! A bunch of people on there whinging and phoning and calling and making me annoyed anyway. Get to Los Angeles, City of Angels. Famously glorious weather all year round, that's why people move there... Pissed down with rain the entire time I was there...
I know you, you hit the storm. I think I moved out of LA and went to New York the day before it turned horrible, didn't I?

The problem was: I hired a car, right? And I was going to get a relatively cheap car. They persuaded me to upgrade to a Mercedes convertible. I thought "Yeah, I'll look good driving around LA." Couldn't use the top down, obviously. Every day I'd get in this car, every day it would be pouring with rain. I could hear it splattering on the fabric roof, thinking "I've just paid four hundred odds for this!" And, you know, every time there'd be a break in the cloud, I would instantly stop, and lower the thing and drive around sub zero temperatures, just to have the top down...
I would like to have seen you...
...Even though it's still cloudy and grim.
...like, you know, at 85 degrees, just whizzing down the freeway at 90 miles an hour. But your glasses would fly off.

They would. This is the problem. I've never really thought-- Plus, I am-- I lost my sunglasses, so I had to wear a hat, in order to keep the sun out me eyes... And all I had-- I thought, I need to take care of me, all I had was kind of -what I like to think is a rather fashionable Justin Timberlake style trilby
Ah, it's not the hat that makes you look like one of Bill and Ben!
See, I think it makes me look like Tom Waits or a sort of 1960s news reporter.
Ah right.
But you've
I thought 'Bill and Ben'. Bill and Ben the Flower Pot Men.
Problem with it is... When I bought it-- Again, I was suckered into it. A bloke sold it to me, told me-- He was a street vendor and he told me I looked amazing in it!
Ricky laughs
I'll be honest-- I honestly gave him the cash straight away.
Did you have a game a 'Find the Lady' with him as well?

I'm beginning to wonder if that was part of his sales pattern, and he wasn't just a lovely fellow who was trying to help me out. But, yeah, it's not quite big enough. So instead of pulling in tight down by the ears, it sort of sits pork pie-esque on top of me head.
Right
And it is in danger of flying off. It did fly off into the back seat when I was driving. Luckily I could stop and pop it back on again.
(laughs) That's great!

It didn't fly off when, you know... You don't want that as you're cruising past a couple of sort of Playboy bunny types in an open top Cadillac and you're just grinning to them and your hat flies off.
Or it hits a big Hell's Angel on a chopper behind you. In the face.
Of course, yeah.
It scratched his bike. You stop and you go "That's my hat" And he goes (in a deep voice) "Is it?"
Exactly.

What annoyed me was, we went-- I was with my mates, we were driving around and we had a bunch of friends and they said "Oh, can you pick up a couple of friends of ours?" And we picked them out, a couple of girls, I thought "Ding-dong! Here we are!" Good looking girls. They got in the car, instantly they were going, "There's not much leg room"

I was thinking "For God's sake! It's a bloody Mercedes! I couldn't even impress these women, and it cost me a fortune! People could go "This is a lovely bit of motor!" But no! Whinging straight away-- We haven't even met before! First thing they said!

Let's accept, right, that at some point, about 13-14 billion years ago, there was nothing. There was no space for nothing to be in. There was no darkness, no light, nothing. Okay? Literally nothing. Except, what is nearly a point in space, that contained everything in the known universe, okay? Suddenly, that exploded, and in a matter of minutes, the universe was pretty much as it is now. And in all the debris, in all the dust, things started to cling together, one of which was the Earth.
Can I have Karl pick up the story from there?
Yeah. So there we are. We've got the Earth, we've got this big...
What happened next?
...Planet
Probably nothing for quite a bit.
Okay
Yeah
Just sort of floated about. But it wasn't causing the problem because it wasn't annoying anyone.
No
See, we don't get a chance of that these days.
No.
You pop something down, someone says: "Move that! Dangerous, what is it?" Back then? Nothing. So it's hanging around... And if you leave something somewhere, something will sit on it.
Right.
Okay. (laughs) "If you leave something somewhere, something will sit on it."
Yeah.
Well, say like a binbag. I can put a binbag outside. Bin men don't come until Friday.
Sure
But I don't want it in the house. There's chicken in it.
Sure. Yeah.
I pop it outside. Right? It sat there for a few days. Now... Just time-- Like a day before the bin men are coming. I pick that up and take it around the front.
Right.
It's got a slug living under it.
Right.
Like one of those little wood lice things might be there... A snail...
Yeah. What's your point? We've got a young earth. It's four and a half billion years ago. It's whizzing around the Sun.
Something's going to sit on it!
Yeah, something had to sort of happened to it. I'll tell you what it's like
Go on
In the same way... Penicillin happened
Go on.
The bread was sat there. It goes off. Air would have... created the greenness.
Ricky laughs
Oh, God! This sounds like the Bible! That is like the Bible! "Air created, the greenness"! That's amazing!
Carry on! Carry on. Because, I'm learning-- I'm learning it.
And once you've got something that leads to other...ness.
(laughs) This is like a monk! That's-- they've sat down...
We all sat cross-legged.
Listening to the wise old man.
Yeah, I know.
"What are you going to do?" "I'm going to write a thing about how everything was created." "Really?"
But hang on, carry on, because I'm interested. So where are we? We had greenness and now we've got something?
So the air created the greenness. And then what is it?
Then we have what was it?
Just otherness.
"Otherness"?
From the greenness. Because once you've got...
From greenness comes otherness!
Once you've got one thing, others come.
Yes.
(laughing) "The air created the greennes! Then you've got otherness!
If you create something, others will come!"
Build it and they will come!
But it's sort of right! In gobbledygook--

No no, I'm discrediting the greenness--  But tell me, take me on, continue this story, because this is fascinating. So where are we now, then? If I was to stand on the Earth at this moment in time, what would I see?
Not that much. You wouldn't want to stay.
But there's greenness.
Little patches of greenness.
Little patches of greenness. Okay.
Little bit of rubble knocking around.
Just a bit of rubble. There's a bit of rubble. Okay.
We've still got a long way to go. We want to get to life, don't we?
Okay, let's skip forward, Karl, to life.
Everything was right, okay? It was the right distance from the Sun. Okay?
But even if it wasn't, we would still have been created.
No we wouldn't have.
Something would have done.
No we wouldn't have. No we wouldn't have!
I want to hear Karl's opinion on this, Rick! I'm not interested in facts, I want to hear Karl's opinion!
So you're saying if the atmosphere around the Earth wasn't about 99% nitrogen, oxygen with 1% other... gases, we'd have still had something else?
Something would have been around. I'm not saying-- It might be better than us, it might be worse than us.
What would it look like?
Well, it's hard to say because they say, don't they, that it's the conditions that mold you into the shape and color and everything else. That makes you the person that you are.
Okay. Let's take Pluto. We know that's the farthest away. So it is dark and cold there
Right.
How do you imagine the creatures that will develop there?
Big eyes and hairy.
Ricky laughs
But how did they evolve? How did they evolve, though?
Because we evolved-- Hang on! You always say animals change to suit the conditions.
I'd have thought if the planet's dark, you don't need eyes, because things that live underground or at the bottom of the ocean, they don't have eyes or color. Because there's no point.
Yeah, but what I'm talking about-- Are we saying we're living inside Pluto or on the top of it like we do here?
Why would we live inside Pluto?
Well, I wouldn't...
It couldn't support life, full stop but... This is one of the most ridiculous conversations we've ever had!
He's seriously considered living inside or outside of Pluto.
Because everything's based on a ridiculously false premise. Karl, listen...
No. We're saying now, that the world's overcrowded. There's too many people on it. We're running out of houses. People are living in basements. Now that's only one step away from being mole-ish.
Ricky laughs
We're already going on the ground because we're running out of space.
(laughing) "From being mole-ish"!
Hang on! Keep going. I want to hear his point!
Is that like being Amish?
So what are you saying?
They don't acknowledge the crust of the Earth.
So you're saying within five years there's going to be sort of mole-like people living in basement flats with no eyes?
But hold on, though-- According to you, the lower they go, the colder and darker they go, the hairier and better eyes they'll have?
Well, it depends. Now I was only saying they'd have better eyes if they were on a dark planet where they're outside, so they still have to look out for things that they could trip over.
Steve & Ricky laugh
If we're going underground...
Because they're so concerned! That's their whole evolution: "We don't want to trip over! I don't want to graze me knees!"
You've got knees! They got them on Earth! Coincidence, innit?
What I'm saying is, right? And I've always said this...
Go on.
We are not the same as the first man that nature made.
No. No, we're not, no.
And that's where we went wrong. And if we didn't interfere, we might have been more suited to the conditions now. Auntie Nora: "Oh, I'm cold!" She doesn't want double glazing.
Why not?
Just 'cause she's worried that, when people come round and sort of knock on the door, she won't hear them. Because it's all sort of double glazed.
But they're knocking on the door.
No, no, but she said-- No, she didn't like a bell, that makes a jump too much.
But how do they get in now?
Well, it's a thin door and thin glass. You hear it. It's not like soundproof, like double glazing is.
So they have to knock on
They knock like that on the door. (knocks on table) And she can hear that, because it's a wooden door.
But why don't they double glaze the door? Is it a glass door?
No, they want to put that PVC door in, with a bit of glass.
Hang on! So she's scared by-- You don't want a doorbell, because that alarms her, but the knocking is fine?
The knocking is fine, because you get to know knocks.
Why don't they have a bell, but when you press it, it makes that noise? (knocks on table)
Because they haven't done that yet.
Well, you could do. You could do a sample of a (knocks) like that, so when they press the doorbell, she hears (knocks). That's easy. That's done. You could sort that out for her.
Well I don't want to start getting dragged into it because...
But why don't you tell her? Say "Auntie Nora, have double glazing! Be warm, be safe! Hear the knock of the bell on the doubley door!" (knocks)
This is it, though, isn't it? She wouldn't be around now, if it wasn't for people interfering, coming up with tablets, making weak people live longer.
Right. You're annoyed at that.
I love-- He's such a fascist, isn't he?! Auntie Nora, a weak person who has been allowed to live.
No but the
Eugenics is where you-- You'd be up here.
Do you recycle and not leave the tap running and turn off lights because you're worried about a child born in 100 years time?
No. No because I don't think... At the end of the day, we have to face facts here.
Go on.
The world is old.
Hold on. Okay.
The world is old?
It's really old.

And it's the same as, if you've got a gram who's 70... There's not much you can do for her. Yeah, you can say you're warm, but at the end of the day, she's still going to be shitting her pants. She's still going to be forgetting things and all the rest of it. And you might be taking care of her, but at the end of the day, the good days are gone.
Right
Yeah?
So in a way, like the world, it's got to a point that it's old-- And yeah, we can say "Turn the tap off, turn the lights off, close the windows, stop letting you eat out"
The Earth metaphorically is shitting its pants.

You've only got to look at what's happening, right? Freezing init at the moment, out there. Ice everywhere. Snow everywhere. Now, an old person, what happens to them? They're always cold. Like the Earth innit? The Earth now is freezing. It feels colder than ever.
It's winter as well, it's also because it's winter.
And I think if you try and make it better now, you end up doing more damage.
Doesn't make sense at all. Doesn't make sense at all.

Well just... Sometimes it's too late to make something better. Like, I've had old relations who smoke, like, 50 a day. Doctor said you got to stop smoking. Stopped smoking, two weeks later, they're dead. Shouldn't have stopped them smoking. Their insides...
Smoking must have kept them alive, is it?
Good advice!
Well, their insides... They're used to all that pollution.
Yeah.
Take the pollution away. What will the will do?
Oh, that's a good point.

Interesting. This is scientifically grounded, is it? You've done a lot of the research, you have a lot of the information about this. Or is it just a wild hair brain speculation again backed up with nothing? Is it bullshit? Which of those two is it?
Like I said to you, I just think-- It's a theory. That's what it is.
Yeah.
You're not telling me it's a coincidence that about three of my old relations have died because the doctor said stop smoking?
Well, it might be because they're very old, and...

Well, they were old, but it's weird how, you know-- Why stop them smoking? They're old. Let them have a fag! Jesus. They've got nothing else in their life. You took that away, they die. Let them have a fag! And it's the same with this world. It's polluted now... I mean, there's rubbish everywhere. Isn't it?
You just mean in the streets and stuff?
Just different levels of-- I've noticed how rubbish changes depending where you live. Just like when I lived in the center of town. It was rank. It was like human sort of poo.
Oh, what?!
Where?
Yeah, down alleys and that.
What? Tramps, you mean?
It must be. I don't know, I didn't see anyone doing it...
Or drug addicts or
But very human. It wasn't dog like
(laughs) How do you know it was human?
Just the way it looked.
What do you mean?
You walk past it and you go "That's-- Look at that there, Suzanne!" I said "Ah, it looks human"
And what did Suzanne say? "Yeah, can we walk somewhere else?"
Why are you walking up and down this same alley?
"I just wanted to show you this human poo!"
Were you having a shit yourself, or...?
It's a cut through that we used to always use. And most of the time it's just like smell a wee, really strong wee
Yeah
And you'd see if you could hold your breath for the full thing.
Steve & Ricky chuckles
A little bit of fun! A little bit of romantic fun after an evening of sitting in a restaurant.
I remember when he took her for a walk around the car park.
(laughs) Lucky lady!
But yeah, now I've moved to like, a posher bit of London, you still get litter. I saw like a rice cake... that someone chucked on the floor.
It's just hummus tubs and...
Yeah. But it's still rubbish innit? It's still rubbish.
Who left this crouton-maker lying around?

So... don't you see what I'm saying, though? The way the world-- We've changed more than the world has. We can't handle anything now, can we? Look at it! Like I say, a bit of snow, a bit of cold, everything comes to a standstill. "Oh, I can't go out, it's dangerous, you'll slip over!" People having time off work.

Yeah. What would you do, right, if you run a business, right? Your business could go under, right? It snows a bit. You got ten employees, you're paying them well. And they go "I can't come in today, the car... It's bit icy"
I'll do it, okay? Right. They're snowed in, right? You're running the business. What are you running?
It's a-- You know, I'm not gonna big myself up. It's just a factory... U-bends. I make U-bends. U-bends for...
...Toilets. So you wanna--? Okay, right, okay.
It's a plumbing thing.
You pay them alright, don't you?
I'd say most of them are on above average.
So you're there. What time do you get in?
About quarter to nine.
Quarter to nine? Waiting for them to come in at nine, yeah?
Okay, right. It's snowing. It's bit snowy. But you got there, took a bit while-- You'd set off earlier, did you, or...?
Gave meself a bit more time, because I had to put the heat in on the car.
Okay. "Ring-ring, ring-ring"
"Hello, KP Plumbing."
"Hello? Is that Mr. Pilkington?"
"Yeah, it is, yeah. Who's that?"
"It's Sheila. Uhmm, listen..."
"Sheila, shouldn't you be here by now?"
"Yeah, no. I was going to set off..."
"Well set off now! Stop wasting time, we've got a big order on!"
"No, I know"
"We're all on a bonus here if we get this done. I'll see you in ten minutes, shall I?"
"I can't make it."
"What?"
"I can't make it."
"Why not?"
"The car won't start and it's slippy on the drive, I just can't get out..."
"Get the transport! I'll see you in-- I'll give you 20 minutes, alright? Don't worry about it! Thanks for calling."
"No, I-- I'm also scared of the ice. I'm scared of the ice. I'm not going to come in today. It's dangerous."
"So what are you going to do?"
"Well, I'm just going to wait until the ice and snow goes away, then I'll come in."
"But they're predicting it's going to be about two weeks before it clears"
"Yeah, I can't really travel in this. It's a bit dangerous."
"Ahh... Well, I'll tell you what, if you stay at home, I'll replace you. Because I need someone to come in, we've got a big order..."
"What? Are you firing me because I can't get into work with this..."
"Well I got into work, Sheila!"
"Yeah, I know, but you don't live with me, do you? If you did live with me, then you'd probably see how..."
"No, it was bad where I was as well, and I'm here!"

Do you know how bad it is here? Why don't you come round and have a look how bad it is here, you drive-- I'll tell you what, you come round and drive my fucking car, because I'm snowed in, you fucking calling me a cunt-- And I'll tell you, if you fire me, I'll take you to tribunal, you bald headed wanker!"
"Right, you fired anyway for that."
"You're in fucking trouble then!"
"Hmmmm. Alight then, see you!" Right. She's done with. She's weak anyway.
"Ring-ring"
"KP Plumbing"
"Hiya, is that Mr. Pilkington?"
"Yeah, it is, yeah."
"Hi, it's Bob here."
"Hi Bob"
"Yeah... Bit of trouble in my area... It's absolutely snowed in and it's possible-- No one's getting out. I live near Sheila by the way..."
"Bob, listen. Yeah, Sheila just been on, she said she can't get in either."

"She can't. I've just seen her out there, trying to dig her car out and she's hurt her back... She's really really tried to get to work, but she can't do it because she's not very rich and her car doesn't work, she hasn't got the right tires, and there's no public transport... they've canceled those... wrong snow... phew, this country... I'm not going to make it in today's, son! So I'll see you tomorrow, aright boy?"
Ricky sniffs
"Well, no, you're saying you'll see me tomorrow..."
"Yeah"
"...but you'll probably call up tomorrow with the same thing."
Well, only because it's snowed in still...
"Now, listen. Well, I can't run a business like this, Bob!"
"Yeah... it's not my fault, is it, really?"
"So go round to Sheila's... and slag me off if you want, but I'll tell you what, you're not coming back here. Fuck off!
One chance. Give them one chance.
Well, you didn't even give them one chance.
No, because they've done it before!
Steve & Ricky laughs
Do you recycle?
I give a lot of stuff to Oxfam.

Well, yeah, that's a sort of recycling, yeah. Hand-me-downs and passing on things. It's probably a better form of recycling, isn't it? You're not destroying anything and remaking it, you're just letting someone else wear a jumper that you don't wear anymore.
I don't really do all that. I don't separate stuff. I don't sort of put-- There's the cans, there's the paper...
You don't do that?
You just throw it away, do you?
That annoys me... when you're just putting it in landfill, mate. Come on!
Yeah
That annoys me, that.
But I haven't all the bins, there isn't enough room for all the bins.
Yeah, we have to do--
You've got a recycle box you stick outside!
What are you on about?
Recycle box, yeah.
Well I haven't got one.
Well, no, you've got to ask for one.

I tried to get rid of a sofa, right? I was getting a new sofa, had the old one. You try and get rid of one of them, it's murder, right? I called up the council, said, I want to get rid of it. They said, we're not coming around there until Friday. It was like a Monday. It's in the way. So I put it outside. They said, if you put it outside, you'll get a fine! I said, "Yeah, but you don't know where I'm going to put it outside."
Yeah
Clever!
Not outside my house! They said "Well, you do that, we've got you..."
"What's the sofa like?" "It's a beige one" "Well, if we see that..."

So they said "If you want to pay to have it collected, we can come and get it tomorrow." 30 quid or something. I said "I'm not paying for it!" It's madness. So hung up. Annoyed. Call me dad up. He said "Oh, I saw this thing on the telly. Saying that you can donate your furniture to people who haven't got a sofa." Looked it up on the internet. So I looked it up. There's a firm that does it.
Right?

Right, cheeky sods... Called them up, said I've got this sofa here, I want to donate it to someone who hasn't got a sofa. They said "Ohh, what's it like? Is it in good condition?" "Yeah, it's all right, yeah." "Why are you getting rid of it?"
Steve laughs

I said because we've moved into a bit of a bigger place and the sofa looks daft in the corner. It's it's too small, so I'm getting a bigger one. There's naught wrong with it. "How big is it? How many people does it sit?" I said it depends how big you are. "You can sit two people on it, but it's not the comfiest. But it's in good condition." It's not even nonsense like stuff. It was expensive when I bought it. He said "Right..." He said "Is it safe?" I said what do you mean? He said "Is it fag proof?" So I said, I don't smoke. He said "Well, go and get the... lift the thing up!" It's now me running around looking at me sofa when I want to givin' it away. I had to lift it up. It had a picture of a fag on it. I said "Yeah, it's got a picture of a fag on it."

Could I just point out -for our American listeners- "fag" is a slang for cigarette. When he says "Is it fag proof?" he's not going to open the cushion and someone's go: "Yuhuuuu! It's meeee!" So, I should explain that straight away.

So anyway, it turned out it was fog proof. They came and picked it up, took it away... But look at the hassle! Look at the hassle it takes to get rid of something! And then they say to you "Do not be dumping stuff on the street!"

You know, it's that thing of having to wait for certain days of the week and you can't always keep hold of something for a certain day of the week because it's big. A mattress. It's one of the things you can't get sort of rid of. Or you can't stick it somewhere.
No.
Because it's in the way. It's a big, clumpy bit of furniture, isn't it?

Yeah. It's not a bit of furniture, really, a mattress, but I know what you mean. "A new sideboard?" "Yeah." "Don't lean on it, it's a bit spongy." "What do you keep in it?" "We can't keep anything in it, it's full of springs and stuff"
No, but you know what I mean.
"It's not a furniture to be honest. It should be on a bed, to be honest."
It's part of a furniture bit, innit? Did I tell you that time when...?
I don't think you'd even ever count a mattress as a piece of furniture.
Of course you can!
It's functional! And where do you start? Is a pillow a piece of furniture? Is a... blanket?
A mug?
"Oh, a nice bit of furniture you're wearing." "They'd be trousers, they're furniture, if you pop them up against a wall!"
Can I tell you that time when we first bought a flat?
Go on.
Bought a flat in Manchester, right?
Yeah.
When you first buy a place, it's expensive, innit?
And it's a big bit of furniture, a flat, innit?
So you know, we bought a sofa, we got a table.
(laughs) Sorry, you don't mean you bought a sofa, you ended up with a table?
No.
Okay, so you've bought a sofa and a table, I see, yeah.
Now, I didn't know--
Suzanne said I should buy a sofa, and I came back with a table
Now, back then I wasn't as wise as I am now.
Steve & Ricky laughs
(laughing) Fuckin' hell! Ohh, what was he? Some snot in a jar?!
Ricky keeps laughing
Can I just apologize to any snot in a jar that's listing, and was offended by that comment?
Alright. So I ordered a bed.
Ricky still laughs
I ordered a bed.
Yeah?
It turned up.
Oh, well done!
(laughing) Fucking hell, that's a big treat! Nothing worked out...
That's not the end of the story, is it?
So I thought, I'm going to get this in the bedroom, set it all up, Suzanne comes home from work, the bed's done, she'd be well happy.
Yeah.
So I get it all up there in the lift and what have you. But it seems like I'm missing something here... Put it together... No mattress!
(laughs) How did you not notice there was no mattress?!
Nom just because it's like I'm thinking "Yeah, I've got all the screws, I've got the slats at the bottom. There's the post and that." I put it together
Where's the softy, spongy bit of furniture, that usually sit on top of the more rigid bit of furniture?

So I called them up and said there's no mattress with it. They said "No, it's not part of it." I said what do you mean, it's not part of it? A bed isn't a bed without a mattress, it's a climbing frame! Right? So they said, you can buy one, we have got them in for that thing. But it was like 400 odd quid.
I don't want you telling me this, I know this. I've bought beds, I understand this is how it works.
The mattress isn't a bed. No, the bed is something else.
Yeah, but that's wrong! You cannot use a bed without a mattress is what I'm saying, so don't sell it without it!
No, but some people replace the bed frame and then keep the old mattress or the other way round.
Thats fine! That's fine, that's fine. Once you've invested in it and you go "Oh, will I buy a new bed or will I just buy a new mattress?" Fine.
Well they're not going to keep selling beds with new mattresses in case you've already got a mattress!
What?
A bed and a mattress without any pillars and blankets is no good. But you don't expect that to come with it.
At least you can sleep on that. You can sleep on a spongy bit. You can chuck a coat over you. You can use a cushion off a sofa.
But they're not thinking some fuckwit might buy it without the mattress, we might include it!
So anyway so I was like "Ahh... didn't think of this..."
(laughing) "I didn't think of this"
So I called me dad up
"So I called me dad up! Dad! It's your fuckwit son again!" "Alright son, how's it going? What have you done? Bought a bed without a mattress?"

So I said "Listen, I bought that bed, there's no mattress on it. Can you get us one?" So he said "Oh, I'll have a word. I'll call around." So he calls back like an hour and a half later. He said "Got you a mattress. Go round to Alf's!" Alf is me, sort of uncle, who isn't an uncle.
Oh alright.
He's the one who I've told you about two tellys, -we've talked about on the podcast- Two tellys. One that works picture-wise and one that works for the sound.
Perfect.
Slept in a rubber dinghy. Right? Now, the thing is...
I remember Alfie.
He said "Yeah, yeah, yeah. Got mattress, come and get it." So I go round there
Why doesn't he sleep on the fucking mattress if he's got one? Why is he sleeping in a fucking boat if he's got a mattress?
He's terrified of flooding.
(laughs) Yeah.
So anyway, I get there and it's in his van.
Right
Sorry, he's driving around with a mattress in the back of a van? What is he, a fucking serial killer?
Ricky laughs

So I thought, Suzanne's gonna be happy. Dragged it out of the van, chucked it in the car, thought, she won't even know. You know what I mean? So I dragged that back and I'm like "Ahh, not gonna make it", it's rush-hour by this point. "Oh, she's going to get home..." Anyway, I get home, drag it into the lift and what have you... Drag it up, drag it into the bedroom, stick it on...
A prostitute falls off it
...Sheet on it, and that. Suzanne comes in. She goes "What is that smell?" So I said "What?" "It's like oil... diesel oil"
Hold on! Why didn't you smell it?
I know, it doesn't make sense!
I think I just sort of got used-- Maybe because I got in the back of the van-- Smelled that, I thought that's in the van. Then I got used to that smell.
Yeah
It's in the back of my car, folded up. I'm concentrating on trying to get this bed made before she gets in.
Sure.
Plus you used to wear a blindfold instead of sunglasses in those days.

So anyway, she's going "What is it?" I said I've got this off Alf's. She said, we can't have that. She said, you know, it's a new flat. Nice, clean flat and everything, we've got this old thing that stinks, get rid of it! It was murder getting rid of that! And I had to tip it. I went around the back of some supermarket and left it there. Because you call around...
Fly-tipping? Illegal fly-tipping?

Well, no, because I think it's illegal and bad when you're chucking it out, say at a bus stop. Or somewhere on a high street or something, and people are going "That looks a mess." I chucked it near the bins at a supermarket. I'd gone out of me way, I thought "Where is this not going to be offensive?"
Why can't you just go to the tip?
I think I did try the tip... Oh, no! There was a massive queue. There was a massive queue!
Ah! Laziness. So laziness, Rick.
Sorry, a queue at the tip?
A massive queue.
I remember it now.
Where was this?
Stratford, that one. I remember.
Why is there a queue for the tip?
I don't know. I remember, yeah, I remember driving past it and "I haven't got time for that."
So don't go on about you couldn't get rid of it, it's because you couldn't be arsed to queue up, you lazy bastard! "Couldn't get rid of it..."!

What was he thinking? Why was he panicking? One: did he get a bed without a mattress? Two: Why does he call his dad to get him out of mattress related problems? His dad goes: "Alf. Alf's got one in the back of a dirty old fucking van!" "Oh right, that should be alright."

No, but the thing is, what I'm saying is, when I was in that bed shop, and I'm going "Oh yeah, good bed, good bed." I'm sitting on it. I'm sitting on a mattress with it. At no point did he say "Now. Have you thought about what sort of mattress you want? Have you got orthopedic problems or whatever?" That didn't come up. He said "There's your order, there's your address..." I'm not a bed man! I go to the bed man to get bed advice! In the same way-- Same problem here! I've had worked on recently with...
"Dad!" "What?" "I'll have to get rid of a body" "Let me call Alf!"
Steve laughs

I've had worked done recently, right? Bathroom retiled. It's been a nightmare. Polish fella. Not a word of English. Which makes it hard. I've got him in as a professional to do it. He's sticking grout down the toilet! So then, like, he sort of finishes...
Is that another mate?

You know, like, after they-- They grout in the tiles to finish it off. Anything that's left, he didn't put it in the bin and get dispose of it properly. He stuck it down the toilet. And now it's there, the grout is there at the bottom of the toilet.
Is it really?
Yeah. With a screw in it.
Well you can drain it, can't you? You can turn the water off, get rid of it. Drain the water.
No, it won't go around the U-bend. It's stuck there.
No, you get it out there. You dry it off, so when there's no water in there...
Just stick your hand in!
Get your hand in there. Why don't you--
Last time I did that-- Last time you called up, when I had me hand down a grid, and you were going "What are you doing? Get someone out to do that!"
Yeah, but... It's putting a Marigold on and taking the screw out, innit?
Oh, yeah, the screw is not a problem. I'm not that bothered about that.
Still down there, is it?
Yeah, the screw is there. Yeah.
So you could have taken that out, no problem.

Yeah, but it's half a job that, innit? I want to get rid of the grout first and I'll get rid of the screw. But I'm not scared about-- You called up here-- I was up to my shoulder, Steve, in like... "glunge"
Ricky & Steve bursts in laughter
"Glunge" is another friend.
What annoys me, Rick, that he makes up his own words...
I'm going to use that for Flanimals, mate!
So you're up to your arm in "glunge"...

Yeah. And Ricky called. And-- Again: it was in Kent. The bloke had done the kitchen, been pouring down cement into the grid outside. I'm sort of washing up, look outside, there's water all over the place. "What's going on here?" I go out there, all the water is like-- Because it runs to a grid outside, you know that sort of system. It's not going down, is it?
Sure

There's loads of water there. So I call up the main fella, who does the kitchens. There's a message there: "Sorry, I'm away in Cyprus" So I can't get hold of him. So he's ballsed it up, but he's on holiday now, he doesn't want to know! There's all this -like I say- gloopy stuff...
"Glunge"

I'm scooping that up with me hand-- Seriously, must be close to my shoulder. Not my problem, really, but all these people-- You're saying "Recycle properly! Don't pour stuff--" All these bottles you get now, Domestos: It has like little pictures of dolphins looking unhappy. Because people are pouring bleach down a sink or whatever. I've never of that problem! I've never upset a dolphin! But I know, if I hadn't sorted that out, it would have caused loads of problems for me and the neighbor, and it would have been my problem. And that's what I'm saying, I'm not that selfish, really, when it comes to the environment.
Start
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

synopsis.description: KP Plumbing is having troubles with their employees

trivia.description: Oxfam is a British-founded confederation of 21 independent charitable organizations focusing on the alleviation of global poverty
Marigold: Yellow rubber glove for household cleaning.
